<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>52 Weeks Ended February&nbsp;1, 2003 Compared with 52 Weeks</B><BR>
<B>Ended February&nbsp;2, 2002</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Sales</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company&#146;s sales increased $398.9&nbsp;million, or 8.2%, during fiscal 2002
to $5.269&nbsp;billion from $4.870&nbsp;billion during fiscal 2001. Contributing to this
improvement was an increase of $231.4&nbsp;million from video game operating segment
sales. Fiscal 2002 sales from Barnes &#038; Noble stores, which contributed 67.8%
of total sales or 91.3% of total bookstore sales, increased 6.4% to $3.575
billion from $3.359&nbsp;billion in fiscal 2001.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The increase in book operating segment sales was primarily attributable to
the 47 new Barnes &#038; Noble stores opened during fiscal 2002. This increase was
partially offset by declining sales of B. Dalton, due to 47 store closings and
a comparable store sales decline of (6.4%) in fiscal 2002.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;GameStop sales during fiscal 2002 increased to $1.353&nbsp;billion from $1.121
billion during fiscal 2001. This increase in sales was primarily attributable
to the 11.4% growth in GameStop comparable store sales and sales from the 210
new GameStop stores opened during fiscal 2002.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Cost of Sales and Occupancy</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company&#146;s cost of sales and occupancy includes costs such as rental
expense, common area


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">F-13
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">
<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">maintenance, merchant association dues and lease-required advertising.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cost of sales and occupancy increased $288.3&nbsp;million, or 8.1%, to $3.847
billion in fiscal 2002 from $3.559&nbsp;billion in fiscal 2001, primarily due to
growth in the video game operating segment. The Company&#146;s gross margin rate
decreased slightly to 27.0% in fiscal 2002 from 26.9% in fiscal 2001.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Selling and Administrative Expenses</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Selling and administrative expenses increased $68.4&nbsp;million, or 7.6%, to
$973.5&nbsp;million in fiscal 2002 from $905.1&nbsp;million in fiscal 2001, primarily due
to the increase in bookstore expenses from the opening of 47 Barnes &#038; Noble
stores in fiscal 2002 and to the growth in the video game operating segment.
Selling and administrative expenses decreased to 18.5% of sales in fiscal 2002
from 18.6% in fiscal 2001. This decrease was primarily attributable to the
lower selling and administrative expenses as a percentage of sales in the video
game operating segment.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Legal Settlement Expense</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In fiscal 2001, the Company recorded a pre-tax charge of $4.5&nbsp;million in
connection with a lawsuit brought by the American Booksellers Association and
26 independent bookstores. The charges included a settlement of $2.4&nbsp;million
paid to the plaintiffs and approximately $2.1&nbsp;million in legal expenses
incurred by the Company.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Depreciation and Amortization</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Depreciation and amortization increased $0.9&nbsp;million, or 0.6%, to $148.7
million in fiscal 2002 from $147.8&nbsp;million in fiscal 2001. The increase was
primarily the result of the increase in depreciation related to the 47 new
Barnes &#038; Noble stores opened during fiscal 2002. This increase was partially
offset by the result of the implementation of SFAS No.&nbsp;142 in fiscal 2002,
whereby goodwill is no longer amortized but is reviewed for impairment at least
annually.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Pre-Opening Expenses</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Pre-opening expenses increased in fiscal 2002 to $10.2&nbsp;million from $8.0
million in fiscal 2001. The increase in pre-opening expenses was primarily the
result of opening 47 new Barnes &#038; Noble stores and 210 new GameStop stores
during fiscal 2002, compared with 40 new Barnes &#038; Noble stores and 74 new
GameStop stores during fiscal 2001.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Impairment Charge</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During the first quarter of fiscal 2002, the Company deemed the decline in
value in its available-for-sale securities in Gemstar and Indigo to be other
than temporary. The investments had been carried at fair market value with
unrealized gains and losses included in shareholders&#146; equity. Events such as
Gemstar&#146;s largest shareholder taking an impairment charge for its investment,
the precipitous decline in the stock price subsequent to the abrupt resignation
of one of its senior executives, the questioning of aggressive revenue
recognition policies and the filing of a class action lawsuit against Gemstar,
were among the items which led to management&#146;s decision to record an impairment
for its investment in Gemstar of nearly $24.0&nbsp;million (before taxes). The
Company&#146;s decision to record an impairment charge for its investment in Indigo
was based on a review of Indigo&#146;s financial condition and historical share
trading data. As a result of these decisions, the Company recorded a non-cash
impairment charge to


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">F-14
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">
<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">operating earnings of $25.3&nbsp;million ($14.9&nbsp;million after taxes) to
reclassify the accumulated unrealized losses and to write down the investments
to their current fair market value at the close of business on May&nbsp;4, 2002.
The investment in Gemstar was sold in the second quarter of fiscal 2002.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Operating Profit</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating profit increased to $264.1&nbsp;million in fiscal 2002 from $245.8
million in fiscal 2001. Operating profit increased to $289.4&nbsp;million, before
the effect of the $25.3&nbsp;million impairment charge during fiscal 2002, from
$250.3&nbsp;million, before the effect of the $4.5&nbsp;million legal settlement expense
during fiscal 2001. Bookstore operating profit decreased 6.4% to $202.4
million, before the effect of the $25.3&nbsp;million impairment charge from $216.2
million, before the effect of the $4.5&nbsp;million legal settlement expense,
primarily attributable to lower comparable store sales. Bookstore operating
margin decreased to 5.2% of sales during fiscal 2002, before the effect of the
impairment charge, from 5.8% of sales during fiscal 2001, before the effect of
the legal settlement expense.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Interest Expense, Net and Amortization of Deferred Financing Fees</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Interest expense, net of interest income, and amortization of deferred
financing fees, decreased $14.8&nbsp;million to $21.5&nbsp;million in fiscal 2002 from
$36.3&nbsp;million in fiscal 2001. The decrease was primarily the result of reduced
borrowings under the Company&#146;s senior credit facility due to the pay down of
debt with proceeds from the GameStop IPO.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Equity in Net Loss of Barnes &#038; Noble.com</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company&#146;s share in the net loss of Barnes &#038; Noble.com, based on an
approximate 36&nbsp;percent equity interest, was $26.8&nbsp;million and $88.4&nbsp;million in
fiscal 2002 and 2001, respectively.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Other Expense</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In fiscal 2002, the Company determined that a decrease in value in certain
of its equity investments occurred which was other than temporary. As a
result, other expense of $16.5&nbsp;million during fiscal 2002 included the
recognition of losses of $11.5&nbsp;million in excess of what would otherwise have
been recognized by application of the equity method in accordance with
Accounting Principles Board Opinion No.&nbsp;18, &#147;The Equity Method of Accounting
for Investments in Common Stock&#148;. The $16.5&nbsp;million loss in other expense was
primarily comprised of $8.5&nbsp;million attributable to iUniverse.com, $5.1&nbsp;million
attributable to <I>BOOK&#174; </I>magazine and $2.4&nbsp;million attributable to enews, inc.
Other expense of $11.7&nbsp;million in fiscal 2001 was due to $4.0&nbsp;million in equity
losses in iUniverse.com, $2.5&nbsp;million in equity losses in <I>BOOK&#174; </I>magazine and
$5.5&nbsp;million in equity losses in enews, inc., partially offset by a one-time
gain of $0.3&nbsp;million from the partial sale of Indigo.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Income Taxes</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Barnes &#038; Noble&#146;s effective tax rate in fiscal 2002 decreased to 40.25
percent compared with 41.50&nbsp;percent during fiscal 2001.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">F-15
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Minority Interest</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During fiscal 2002, minority interest for GameStop was $19.1&nbsp;million based
on a 36.5% basic weighted average ownership interest.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Earnings</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As a result of the factors discussed above, the Company reported
consolidated net earnings of $99.9&nbsp;million (or $1.39 per share) during fiscal
2002 compared with net earnings of $64.0&nbsp;million (or $0.94 per share) during
fiscal 2001. Components of diluted earnings per share are as follows:

</DIV>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Seasonality</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company&#146;s business, like that of many retailers, is seasonal, with the
major portion of sales and operating profit realized during the quarter which
includes the holiday selling season.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Liquidity and Capital Resources</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Working capital requirements are generally at their highest in the
Company&#146;s fiscal quarter ending on or about January&nbsp;31 due to the higher
payments to vendors for holiday season merchandise purchases. In addition, the
Company&#146;s sales and merchandise inventory levels will fluctuate from quarter to
quarter as a result of the number and timing of new store openings, as well as
the amount and timing of sales contributed by new stores.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cash flows from operating activities, funds available under its revolving
credit facility and short-term vendor financing continue to provide the Company
with liquidity and capital resources for store expansion, seasonal working
capital requirements and capital investments.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
February&nbsp;2002, the Company completed an IPO
for its GameStop subsidiary, raising $250.0&nbsp;million in cash for the Company
(which was used to pay down debt) and $98.0&nbsp;million in net proceeds for
GameStop. As a result of the IPO, the Company retained an approximate 63
percent interest in GameStop.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">F-16
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Cash Flow</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cash flows provided from operating activities were $509.0&nbsp;million, $329.0
million and $457.4&nbsp;million during fiscal 2003, 2002 and 2001, respectively. In
fiscal 2003, the increase in cash flows from operating activities was primarily
attributable to improved working capital management and an increase in net
earnings. In fiscal 2002, the decrease in cash flows from operating activities
was primarily attributable to a weaker-than-expected holiday season, as well as
the increase in inventory due to the Reno distribution center becoming fully
operational. In fiscal 2001, the increase in cash flows from operating
activities was primarily attributable to increased accounts payable leverage
and improvement in net earnings.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The weighted-average age per square foot of the Company&#146;s 647 Barnes &#038;
Noble stores was 6.5&nbsp;years as of January&nbsp;31, 2004 and is expected to increase
to approximately 7.1&nbsp;years by January&nbsp;29, 2005. As the Barnes &#038; Noble stores
continue to mature, and as the number of new stores opened during the fiscal
year decreases as a percentage of the existing store base, the increasing
operating profits of Barnes &#038; Noble stores are expected to generate a greater
portion of the cash flows required for working capital, including new store
inventories, capital expenditures and other initiatives.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Capital Structure</I>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Strong cash flows from operations and a continued emphasis on working
capital management strengthened the Company&#146;s balance sheet in fiscal 2003.
Shareholders&#146; equity increased 22.6% to $1.260&nbsp;billion as of January&nbsp;31, 2004,
from $1.028&nbsp;billion as of February&nbsp;1, 2003.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In fiscal 2002, the Company obtained a $500.0&nbsp;million three-year senior
revolving credit facility (the Facility) with a syndicate of banks led by Fleet
National Bank as administrative agent. The Facility, which was to expire in May
2005, replaced the Company&#146;s $850.0&nbsp;million senior credit facility. In fiscal
2003, the Company exercised its option to extend $490.0&nbsp;million of its $500.0
million Facility for one additional year, through May&nbsp;2006. The Facility
permits borrowings at various interest-rate options based on the prime rate or
London Interbank Offer Rate (LIBOR)&nbsp;plus applicable margin depending upon the
level of the Company&#146;s fixed charge coverage ratio. The Company&#146;s fixed charge
coverage is calculated as the ratio of earnings before interest, taxes,
depreciation, amortization and rents to interest plus rents. In addition, the
Facility requires the Company to pay a commitment fee of 0.25&nbsp;percent, which
varies based upon the Company&#146;s fixed charge coverage ratio, calculated as a
percentage of the unused portion. The Company is required to pay utilization
fees of 0.125&nbsp;percent or 0.25&nbsp;percent on all outstanding loans under the
Facility if the aggregate outstanding loans are greater than 33&nbsp;percent and 66
percent, respectively, of the aggregate amount of the Facility.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A portion of the Facility, not to exceed $100.0&nbsp;million, is available for
the issuance of letters of credit. Also, under certain circumstances, the
Company may be permitted to increase the size of the Facility to an amount not
to exceed $600.0&nbsp;million.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In fiscal 2001, the Company issued $300.0&nbsp;million of 5.25&nbsp;percent
convertible subordinated notes due March&nbsp;15, 2009. The notes are convertible
into the Company&#146;s common stock at a conversion price of $32.512 per share. At
the Company&#146;s option, it may redeem the notes at a premium to par beginning on
March&nbsp;20, 2004.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Borrowings under the Company&#146;s convertible subordinated notes and senior
credit facilities averaged $342.5&nbsp;million, $377.3&nbsp;million and $689.3&nbsp;million
and peaked at $474.2&nbsp;million, $490.3&nbsp;million


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">F-17
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">
<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">and $870.0&nbsp;million during fiscal 2003, 2002 and 2001, respectively. The ratio
of debt to equity improved to 0.24:1.00 as of January&nbsp;31, 2004 from 0.29:1.00
as of February&nbsp;1, 2003, primarily due to the increase in net earnings and stock
option exercise proceeds.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Capital Investment</I>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Capital expenditures totaled $163.4&nbsp;million, $179.5&nbsp;million and $168.8
million during fiscal 2003, 2002 and 2001, respectively. Capital expenditures
in fiscal 2004, primarily for the opening of between 30 and 35 new Barnes &#038;
Noble stores, between 300 and 330 GameStop stores and the opening of a new
distribution center scheduled for 2006 are expected to be between $225&nbsp;million
and $250&nbsp;million, although commitment to many of such expenditures has not yet
been made.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Based on current operating levels and the store expansion planned for the
next fiscal year, management believes cash flows generated from operating
activities, short-term vendor financing and borrowing capacity under the
Facility will be sufficient to meet the Company&#146;s working capital and debt
service requirements, and support the development of its short- and long-term
strategies for at least the next 12&nbsp;months.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In fiscal 1999, the Board of Directors authorized a common stock
repurchase program for the purchase of up to $250.0&nbsp;million of the Company&#146;s
common shares. As of January&nbsp;31, 2004, the Company has repurchased 8,807,700
shares at a cost of approximately $189.7&nbsp;million under this program. The
repurchased shares are held in treasury.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In fiscal 2002, the Company announced its intent to purchase up to $10.0
million of Barnes &#038; Noble.com Class&nbsp;A Common Stock in the open market or
through privately negotiated transactions. The Company purchased approximately
3.0&nbsp;million shares of Barnes &#038; Noble.com Class&nbsp;A Common Stock for $3.3&nbsp;million.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On September&nbsp;15, 2003, the Company completed its acquisition of all of
Bertelsmann&#146;s interest in Barnes &#038; Noble.com. The purchase price paid by the
Company was $165.4&nbsp;million (including acquisition related costs) in a
combination of cash and a note, equivalent to $2.80 per share or membership
unit in Barnes &#038; Noble.com. The note issued to Bertelsmann in the amount of
$82.0&nbsp;million was paid off in the fourth quarter of fiscal 2003. As a result
of the acquisition, the Company increased its economic interest in Barnes &#038;
Noble.com to approximately 75&nbsp;percent. Subsequent to the purchase, Barnes &#038;
Noble.com employees exercised 3.9&nbsp;million stock options thereby reducing the
Company&#146;s economic interest in Barnes &#038; Noble.com to approximately 73&nbsp;percent.
On January&nbsp;8, 2004, the Company and bn.com entered into a definitive merger
agreement. Under the terms of the merger, the holders of bn.com&#146;s outstanding
common stock, other than that owned by the Company and its subsidiaries, will
be entitled to receive $3.05 in cash for each share that they own. As a result
of this transaction, bn.com will become wholly owned by the Company. The
closing of the merger is expected to occur during the second quarter of fiscal
2004.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">F-18
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

    <TD align="right">737.2</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Off-Balance Sheet Arrangements</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As of January&nbsp;31, 2004, the Company had no off-balance sheet arrangements
as defined in Item&nbsp;303 of the Regulation&nbsp;S-K.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Impact of Inflation</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company does not believe that inflation has had a material effect on
its net sales or results of operations.

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See footnote 21 to the Notes to Consolidated
Financial Statements.

<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Newly Issued Accounting Pronouncements</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In December&nbsp;2003, the Financial Accounting Standards Board issued SFAS No.
132 (Revised 2003), &#147;Employers&#146; Disclosures about Pensions and Other
Post-retirement Benefits and amendment of FASB Statements No.&nbsp;87, 88 and 106&#148;.
This Statement revises employers&#146; disclosures about pension plans and other
post-retirement benefit plans. The disclosures required by this Statement are
effective for fiscal years ending after December&nbsp;15, 2003. The Company has
incorporated these expanded disclosures into the footnotes to the Company&#146;s
financial statements included herein.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Disclosure Regarding Forward-Looking Statements</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;This report may contain certain forward-looking statements (within the
meaning of Section&nbsp;27A of the Securities Act of 1933 and Section&nbsp;21E of the
Securities Exchange Act of 1934) and information relating to the Company that
are based on the beliefs of the management of the Company as well as
assumptions made by and information currently available to the management of
the Company. When used in this report, the words &#147;anticipate,&#148; &#147;believe,&#148;
&#147;estimate,&#148; &#147;expect,&#148; &#147;intend,&#148; &#147;plan&#148; and similar expressions, as they relate
to the Company or the management of the Company, identify forward-looking
statements. Such statements reflect the current views of the Company with
respect to future events, the outcome of which is subject to certain risks,
including among others general economic and market conditions, decreased
consumer demand for the Company&#146;s products, possible disruptions in the
Company&#146;s computer or telephone systems, possible work stoppages or increases
in labor costs, possible increases in shipping rates or interruptions in
shipping service, effects of competition, possible disruptions or delays in the
opening of new stores or the inability to obtain suitable sites for new stores,
higher-than-anticipated store closing or relocation costs, higher interest
rates, the performance of the Company&#146;s online initiatives such as Barnes &#038;
Noble.com, the performance and successful integration of acquired businesses,
the success of the Company&#146;s strategic investments, unanticipated increases in
merchandise or occupancy costs, unanticipated adverse litigation results or
effects, and other factors which may be outside of the Company&#146;s control. In
addition, the video-game market has historically been cyclical in nature and
dependent upon the introduction of new generation systems and related
interactive software. Should one or more of these risks or uncertainties
materialize, or should underlying assumptions prove incorrect, actual results
or outcomes may vary materially from those described as anticipated, believed,
estimated, expected, intended or planned. Subsequent written and oral
forward-looking statements attributable to the Company or persons acting on its
behalf are expressly qualified in their entirety by the cautionary statements
in this paragraph.

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>CONSOLIDATED STATEMENTS OF

<DIV align="center">
<TABLE style="font-size: 10pt" cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%">
<!-- Begin Table Head -->
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD width="46%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See accompanying notes to

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">F-24
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">





<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">(Thousands of dollars, except per share data)<BR>
For the 52&nbsp;weeks ended January&nbsp;31, 2004 (fiscal 2003), 52&nbsp;weeks ended February
1, 2003 (fiscal 2002) and 52&nbsp;weeks ended February&nbsp;2, 2002 (fiscal 2001).



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>1. Summary of Significant Accounting Policies</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Business</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Barnes &#038; Noble, Inc. (Barnes &#038; Noble), through its subsidiaries
(collectively, the Company), is primarily engaged in the sale of books, video
games and entertainment-software products. The Company employs two principal
bookselling strategies: its superstore strategy through its wholly owned
subsidiary Barnes &#038; Noble Booksellers, Inc., primarily under its Barnes &#038; Noble
Booksellers trade name (hereafter collectively referred to as Barnes &#038; Noble
stores) and its mall strategy through its wholly owned subsidiary B. Dalton
Bookseller, Inc. primarily under its B. Dalton store trade name (hereafter
collectively referred to as B. Dalton stores). The Company publishes books
under its own imprints which, since January&nbsp;2003, also include Sterling
Publishing Co., Inc. (Sterling Publishing) and its various imprints. The
Company is also engaged in the online retailing of books and other products
through an approximate 73&nbsp;percent interest in barnesandnoble.com llc (Barnes &#038;
Noble.com), as more fully described in Note 8. The Company currently has an
approximate 64&nbsp;percent economic interest in GameStop Corp., the operator of
video-game and entertainment-software stores primarily under the GameStop trade
name, and a Web site (www.gamestop.com), and publisher of <I>Game Informer</I>
magazine (hereafter collectively referred to as GameStop stores). Additionally,
the Company owns an approximate 74&nbsp;percent interest in Calendar Club L.L.C.
(Calendar Club), an operator of seasonal kiosks.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Consolidation</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The consolidated financial statements include the accounts of Barnes &#038;
Noble and its wholly and majority-owned subsidiaries. Barnes &#038; Noble.com
reports its results based on a calendar year, and accordingly their financial
statements are consolidated on that basis. Investments in affiliates in which
ownership interests range from 20&nbsp;percent to 50&nbsp;percent, are accounted for
under the equity method. All significant intercompany accounts and transactions
have been eliminated in consolidation.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Use of Estimates</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In preparing financial statements in conformity with generally accepted
accounting principles, the Company is required to make estimates and
assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities and the
disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the financial
statements and revenues and expenses during the reporting period. Actual
results could differ from those estimates.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Cash and Cash Equivalents</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company considers all short-term, highly liquid instruments purchased
with an original maturity of three months or less to be cash equivalents.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">F-25
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS CONTINUED</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Merchandise Inventories</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Merchandise inventories are stated at the lower of cost or market. Cost
is determined primarily by the retail inventory method on the first-in,
first-out (FIFO)&nbsp;basis for 77&nbsp;percent and 82&nbsp;percent of the Company&#146;s
merchandise inventories as of January&nbsp;31, 2004 and February&nbsp;1, 2003,
respectively. Merchandise inventories of GameStop, Barnes &#038; Noble.com, and
Calendar Club represent 19&nbsp;percent and
12&nbsp;percent of merchandise inventories as of January&nbsp;31, 2004 and February&nbsp;1,
2003, respectively, and are recorded based on the average cost method. The
remaining merchandise inventories are valued on the last-in, first-out (LIFO)
method.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;If substantially all of the merchandise inventories currently valued at
LIFO costs were valued at current costs, merchandise inventories would remain
unchanged as of January&nbsp;31, 2004 and February&nbsp;1, 2003.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Property and Equipment</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Property and equipment are carried at cost, less accumulated depreciation
and amortization. For financial reporting purposes, depreciation is computed
using the straight-line method over estimated useful lives. For tax purposes,
different methods are used. Maintenance and repairs are expensed as incurred,
while improvements and major remodeling costs are capitalized. Leasehold
improvements are capitalized and amortized over the shorter of their estimated
useful lives or the terms of the respective leases. Capitalized lease
acquisition costs are being amortized over the lease terms of the underlying
leases. Costs incurred in purchasing management information systems are
capitalized and included in property and equipment. These costs are amortized
over their estimated useful lives from the date the systems become operational.
Internally developed software is expensed as incurred.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Other Long-Lived Assets</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company&#146;s other long-lived assets include property and equipment and
amortizable intangibles. At January&nbsp;31, 2004, the Company had $686,649 of
property and equipment, net of accumulated depreciation, and $20,156 of
amortizable intangible assets, net of amortization, accounting for
approximately 20.2% of the Company&#146;s total assets. The Company reviews its
long-lived assets for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances
indicate that the carrying amount of an asset may not be recoverable in
accordance with Statement of Financial Accounting Standards (SFAS)&nbsp;No.&nbsp;144,
&#147;Accounting for the Impairment or Disposal of Long-Lived Assets&#148;.
Recoverability of assets held and used are measured by a comparison of the
carrying amount of an asset to undiscounted pre-tax future net cash flows.
Future events could cause the Company to conclude that impairment indicators
exist and that long-lived assets may be impaired. Any resulting impairment loss
could have a material adverse impact on the Company&#146;s financial condition and
results of operations.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Goodwill and Unamortizable Intangible Assets</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The costs in excess of net assets of businesses acquired are carried as
goodwill in the accompanying consolidated balance sheets.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At January&nbsp;31, 2004, the Company had $509,244 of goodwill and $74,418 of
unamortizable intangible assets (i.e. those with an indefinite life),
accounting for approximately 16.6% of the Company&#146;s total assets. SFAS No.
142, &#147;Goodwill and Other Intangible Assets&#148;, requires that goodwill and other
unamortizable intangible assets no longer be amortized, but instead be tested
for impairment at


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">F-26
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED
FINANCIAL STATEMENTS CONTINUED</B>
<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">least annually or earlier if there are impairment indicators. The Company
performs a two-step process for impairment testing of goodwill as required by
SFAS No.&nbsp;142. The first step of this test, used to identify potential
impairment, compares the fair value of a reporting unit with its carrying
amount. The second step (if necessary) measures the amount of the impairment.
The Company completed its annual impairment test on the goodwill in November
2003 and deemed that no impairment charge was necessary. The Company has noted
no subsequent indicators of impairment. The Company tests unamortizable
intangible assets by comparing the fair value and the carrying value of such
assets. Changes in market conditions, among other factors, could have a
material impact on these estimates.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The effect of adoption of SFAS No.&nbsp;142 on the reported net income (loss)&nbsp;is
as follows:

</DIV>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Deferred Charges</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Costs incurred to obtain long-term financing are amortized over the terms
of the respective debt agreements using the straight-line method, which
approximates the interest method. Unamortized costs included in other
noncurrent assets as of January&nbsp;31, 2004 and February&nbsp;1, 2003 were $9,732 and
$11,130, respectively. Amortization expense included in interest and
amortization of deferred financing fees were $2,916, $2,894 and $2,292 during
fiscal 2003, 2002 and 2001, respectively.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Derivative Instruments</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Under an agreement which expired February&nbsp;3, 2003, the Company used an
interest-rate swap as a derivative to modify the interest characteristics of
its outstanding floating rate debt, thereby reducing its exposure to
fluctuations in interest rates. The Company&#146;s accounting policy was based on
its designation of such instruments as cash flow hedges whereby changes in the
fair value in the derivative have been included in other comprehensive income.
The Company did not enter into the contract for speculative purposes.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Revenue Recognition</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Revenue from sales of the Company&#146;s products is recognized at the time of
sale. Sales returns (which are not significant) are recognized at the time
returns are made.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">F-27
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS CONTINUED</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Barnes &#038; Noble Membership Program entitles the customer to receive a
10&nbsp;percent discount on all purchases made during the twelve-month membership
period. The annual membership fee of $25.00 is non-refundable after the first
30&nbsp;days of the membership term. Revenue is being recognized over the
twelve-month membership period based upon historical spending patterns for
Barnes &#038; Noble customers. Refunds of membership fees due to cancellations
within the first 30&nbsp;days are minimal.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Subscription revenue is recognized on a straight-line basis as magazine
issues are delivered.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Advertising Costs</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The costs of advertising are expensed as incurred during the year pursuant
to Statement of Position 93-7, &#147;Reporting on Advertising Costs&#148;. In addition,
consideration received from vendors in conjunction with the Company&#146;s
cooperative advertising program is netted against the related expenses.
Advertising costs are charged to selling and administrative expenses. As a
result of the adoption of requirements set forth in Emerging Issues Task Force
(EITF)&nbsp;Issue 02-16, &#147;Accounting by a Customer (Including a Reseller) for
Certain Consideration Received from a Vendor&#148;, which are effective for
arrangements entered into after December&nbsp;31, 2002, the Company has reclassified
some of its co-op advertising from an offset to selling and administrative
expenses to a reduction in costs of sales and occupancy. The implementation of
EITF Issue 02-16 did not have a material effect on the Company&#146;s annual results
of operations.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Closed Store Expenses</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;When the Company closes or relocates a store, the Company charges
unrecoverable costs to expense. Such costs include the net book value of
abandoned fixtures and leasehold improvements and, when a store is closed, a
provision for future lease obligations, net of expected sublease recoveries.
Costs associated with store closings of $5,952, $10,111 and $9,831 during
fiscal 2003, 2002 and 2001, respectively, are included in selling and
administrative expenses in the accompanying consolidated statements of
operations.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Net Earnings Per Common Share</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Basic earnings per share is computed by dividing income available to
common shareholders by the weighted-average number of common shares
outstanding. Diluted earnings per share reflect, in periods in which they have
a dilutive effect, the impact of common shares issuable upon exercise of the
Company&#146;s and GameStop&#146;s outstanding stock options and with respect to the
Company&#146;s deferred compensation plan, and assumes the conversion of the
Company&#146;s 5.25% convertible subordinated notes for the period outstanding since
their issuance in March&nbsp;2001.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Income Taxes</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The provision for income taxes includes federal, state and local income
taxes currently payable and those deferred because of temporary differences
between the financial statement and tax bases of assets and liabilities. The
deferred tax assets and liabilities are measured using the enacted tax rates
and laws that are expected to be in effect when the differences reverse.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">F-28
</DIV>

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Reclassifications</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Certain prior-period amounts have been reclassified for comparative
purposes to conform with the fiscal 2003 presentation.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Reporting Period</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company&#146;s fiscal year is comprised of 52 or 53&nbsp;weeks, ending on the
Saturday closest to the last day of January. The reporting periods ended
January&nbsp;31, 2004, February&nbsp;1, 2003 and February&nbsp;2, 2002 contained 52&nbsp;weeks.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Newly Issued Accounting Pronouncements</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In December&nbsp;2003, the Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB)&nbsp;issued
SFAS No.&nbsp;132 (Revised 2003), &#147;Employers&#146; Disclosures about Pensions and Other
Post-retirement Benefits and amendment of FASB Statements No.&nbsp;87, 88 and 106&#148;.
This Statement revises employers&#146; disclosures about pension plans and other
post-retirement benefit plans. The disclosures required by this Statement

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>3. Debt</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On May&nbsp;22, 2002, the Company obtained a $500,000 three-year senior
revolving credit facility (the Facility) with a syndicate of banks led by Fleet
National Bank as administrative agent. The Facility, which was to expire in
May&nbsp;2005, replaced the Company&#146;s $850,000 five-year senior revolving credit
facility obtained on November&nbsp;18, 1997. In fiscal 2003, the Company exercised
its option to extend $490,000 of its $500,000 Facility for one additional year,
through May&nbsp;2006. The Facility permits borrowings at various interest-rate
options based on the prime rate or London Interbank Offer Rate (LIBOR)&nbsp;plus
applicable margin depending upon the level of the Company&#146;s fixed charge
coverage ratio. The Company&#146;s fixed charge coverage is calculated as the ratio
of earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, amortization and rents to
interest plus rents. In addition, the Facility requires the Company to pay a
commitment fee of 0.25&nbsp;percent, which varies based upon the Company&#146;s fixed
charge coverage ratio, calculated as a percentage of the unused portion. The
Company is required to pay utilization fees of 0.125&nbsp;percent or 0.25&nbsp;percent on
all outstanding loans under the Facility if the aggregate outstanding loans are
greater than 33&nbsp;percent and 66&nbsp;percent, respectively, of the aggregate amount
of the Facility.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A portion of the Facility, not to exceed $100,000, is available for the
issuance of letters of credit. Also, under certain circumstances, the Company
may increase the size of the Facility to an amount not to exceed $600,000.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Mandatory prepayments include the requirement that loans outstanding under
the Facility be reduced by 100&nbsp;percent of the net cash proceeds from (i)&nbsp;the
disposition of the Company&#146;s stock in certain entities, (ii)&nbsp;any equity
issuance, and (iii)&nbsp;the disposition of certain other material assets, other
than those assets disposed of during the ordinary course of business. Under
certain circumstances, mandatory commitment reductions may include the
requirement that the aggregate size of the Facility be reduced upon the
disposition by the Company of its stock in GameStop.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Facility contains covenants, limitations and events of default typical
of credit facilities of this size and nature, including financial covenants,
which require the Company to meet, among other



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">F-30
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>
<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS CONTINUED</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">things, leverage and fixed
charge coverage ratios and which limit capital expenditures. Negative covenants
include limitations on other indebtedness, liens, investments, mergers,
consolidations, sales or leases of assets, acquisitions, distributions and
dividends and other payments in respect of capital stock, transactions with
affiliates, and sale/leaseback transactions. In the event the Company defaults
on these financial covenants, all outstanding borrowings under the Facility may
become immediately payable and no further borrowings may be available. The
Facility is secured by the Company&#146;s capital stock in its subsidiaries, and by
the accounts receivable and certain general intangibles of the Company and its
subsidiaries. Net proceeds from the Facility are available for general
corporate purposes.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In fiscal 2001, the Company issued $300,000, 5.25&nbsp;percent convertible
subordinated notes due March&nbsp;15, 2009. The notes are convertible into the
Company&#146;s common stock at a conversion price of $32.512 per share. At the
Company&#146;s option, it may redeem the notes at a premium to par beginning on
March&nbsp;20, 2004.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company from time to time enters into interest rate swap agreements to
manage interest-costs and risk associated with changes in interest rates. These
agreements effectively convert underlying variable-rate debt based on prime
rate or LIBOR to fixed-rate debt through the exchange of fixed and floating
interest payment obligations without the exchange of underlying principal
amounts. For each of the years ended January&nbsp;31, 2004 and February&nbsp;1, 2003, the
Company had a notional amount outstanding of $0 and $55,000, respectively.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Selected information related to the Company&#146;s convertible subordinated
notes and revolving credit facility:

<TABLE style="font-size: 10pt" cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="85%">

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Fees expensed with respect to the unused portion of the Facility were
$1,170, $999 and $516, during fiscal 2003, 2002 and 2001, respectively.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The amounts outstanding under the Facility have been classified as
long-term debt based on the Company&#146;s ability to continually maintain principal
amounts outstanding.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company has no agreements to maintain compensating balances.

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>4. Fair Values of Financial Instruments</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The carrying values of cash and cash equivalents reported in the
accompanying consolidated balance sheets approximate fair value due to the
short-term maturities of these assets. The aggregate fair value of the
Facility approximates its carrying amount because of its recent and frequent
repricing based upon market conditions.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Interest-rate swap agreements are valued based on market quotes obtained
from dealers. There were no interest rate swap agreements outstanding at
January&nbsp;31, 2004. The estimated fair value of


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">F-31

    <TD align="right"><HR size="4" noshade>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<!-- End Table Body -->
</TABLE>
</DIV>



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">F-33
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS CONTINUED</B>

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>8. Barnes &#038; Noble.com Acquisition</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On November&nbsp;12, 1998, the Company and Bertelsmann AG (Bertelsmann)
completed the formation of Barnes &#038; Noble.com to operate the online retail
bookselling operations of the Company&#146;s wholly owned subsidiary,
barnesandnoble.com inc. (bn.com). Under the terms of the relevant agreements,
effective as of October&nbsp;31, 1998, the Company and Bertelsmann each retained a
50&nbsp;percent membership interest in Barnes &#038; Noble.com. The Company contributed
substantially all of the assets and liabilities of its online operations to the
joint venture and Bertelsmann paid $75,000 to the Company and made a $150,000
cash contribution to the joint venture. Bertelsmann also agreed to contribute
an additional $50,000 to the joint venture for future working capital
requirements. The Company recognized a pre-tax gain during fiscal 1998 in the
amount of $126,435, of which $63,759 was recognized in earnings based on the
$75,000 received directly and $62,676 ($36,351 after taxes) was reflected in
additional paid-in capital based on the Company&#146;s share of the incremental
equity of the joint venture resulting from the $150,000 Bertelsmann
contribution.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On May&nbsp;25, 1999, bn.com completed an IPO of 28.75&nbsp;million shares of Class
A Common Stock and used the proceeds to purchase a 20&nbsp;percent interest in
Barnes &#038; Noble.com. As a result, the Company and Bertelsmann each retained a
40&nbsp;percent interest in Barnes &#038; Noble.com. The Company recorded an
increase in additional paid-in capital of $116,158 after taxes
representing the Company&#146;s incremental share in the equity of Barnes &#038;
Noble.com. Under the terms of the November&nbsp;12, 1998 joint


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">F-34
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">
<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS CONTINUED</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">venture agreement
between the Company and Bertelsmann, the Company received a $25,000 payment
from Bertelsmann in connection with the IPO. The Company recognized the
$25,000 pre-tax gain in fiscal 1999.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In November&nbsp;2000, Barnes &#038; Noble.com acquired Fatbrain.com, Inc.
(Fatbrain) through a merger with bn.com. Bn.com issued shares of its common
stock to Fatbrain shareholders as partial consideration for the merger. As a
result of this acquisition, the Company and Bertelsmann each retained an
approximate 36&nbsp;percent interest in Barnes &#038; Noble.com. In October&nbsp;2002, the
Company announced its intent to purchase up to $10,000 of bn.com Class&nbsp;A Common
Stock in the open market or through privately negotiated transactions. The
Company purchased approximately 3.0&nbsp;million shares of bn.com Class&nbsp;A Common
Stock, bringing its economic ownership of Barnes &#038; Noble.com to approximately
38&nbsp;percent.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On September&nbsp;15, 2003, the Company completed its acquisition of all of
Bertelsmann&#146;s interest in Barnes &#038; Noble.com. The purchase price paid by the
Company was $165,406 (including acquisition related costs) in a combination of
cash and a note, equivalent to $2.80 per share or membership unit in bn.com.
The note issued to Bertelsmann in the amount of $82,000 was paid in the fourth
quarter of fiscal 2003. As a result of the acquisition, the Company increased
its economic interest in Barnes &#038; Noble.com to approximately 75&nbsp;percent.
Subsequent to the purchase, Barnes &#038; Noble.com employees exercised 3.9&nbsp;million
options to acquire stock in bn.com, with the resulting proceeds being used to
acquire membership units in Barnes &#038; Noble.com, thereby reducing the Company&#146;s
economic interest in Barnes &#038; Noble.com to approximately 73&nbsp;percent. The
acquisition was accounted for by the purchase method of accounting and,
accordingly, the results of operations for the period subsequent to the
acquisition are included in the consolidated financial statements.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Based upon a preliminary assessment of the fair values, the allocation of
the purchase price to the proportionate amount of assets acquired and
liabilities assumed was as follows:

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Hardware and software have been assigned a preliminary estimated useful
life of four years. The customer list and relationships intangible asset has
been assigned a preliminary estimated useful life of four years to be amortized
on an accelerated basis based on estimated usage where a substantial portion of
the asset will be amortized in the first year. The above preliminary purchase
price allocation is subject to revision as more detailed analysis is completed
and additional information on the fair value of assets and liabilities of
Barnes &#038; Noble.com becomes available. The final allocation to goodwill and the
trade name (which is considered to have an indefinite life and will not be
amortized) will be tested at least annually for impairment in accordance with
SFAS No.&nbsp;142.

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The information has been prepared for comparative purposes only and does
not purport to be indicative of the results of operations which actually would
have occurred had the acquisition taken place on the date indicated, or which
may result in the future.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On January&nbsp;8, 2004, the Company and bn.com entered into a definitive
merger agreement. Under the terms of the merger, the holders of bn.com&#146;s
outstanding common stock, other than that owned by the Company and its
subsidiaries, will be entitled to receive $3.05 in cash for each share that
they own. As a result of this transaction, bn.com will become wholly owned by
the Company. The closing of the merger is expected to occur during the second
quarter of fiscal 2004.

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>9. Other Acquisitions</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During fiscal 2003, the Company, through its approximate 64&nbsp;percent owned
subsidiary GameStop Corp. (GameStop), acquired a controlling interest in
Gamesworld Group Limited (Gamesworld), an Ireland-based electronic games
retailer, for $3,279 in cash. The acquisition was accounted for by the purchase
method of accounting and, accordingly, the results of operations for the period
subsequent to the acquisition are included in the consolidated financial
statements. The excess of purchase price over the fair value of the net assets
acquired, in the amount of $2,869, has been recorded as goodwill and will be
tested annually for impairment in accordance with SFAS No.&nbsp;142. The pro forma
effect assuming the acquisition of Gamesworld at the beginning of fiscal 2002
is not material.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In fiscal 2002, the Company acquired Sterling Publishing, one of the top
25 publishers in the nation and the industry&#146;s leading publisher of how-to
books. The acquisition was accounted for by the purchase method of accounting
and, accordingly, the results of operations for the period subsequent to the
acquisition are included in the consolidated financial statements. The excess
of purchase price over the fair value of the net assets acquired has been
recorded as goodwill and other intangible assets and will be tested annually
for impairment in accordance with SFAS No.&nbsp;142. The pro forma effect assuming
the acquisition of Sterling Publishing at the beginning of fiscal 2002 is not
material.

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>10. Employees&#146; Retirement and Defined Contribution Plans</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As of December&nbsp;31, 1999, substantially all employees of the Company were
covered under a noncontributory defined benefit pension plan (the Pension
Plan). As of January&nbsp;1, 2000, the Pension


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">F-36

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Plan was amended so that employees
no longer earn benefits for subsequent service. Subsequent service continues
to be the basis for vesting of benefits not yet vested at December&nbsp;31, 1999 and
the Pension Plan will continue to hold assets and pay benefits.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company maintains defined contribution plans (the Savings Plans) for
the benefit of substantially all employees. In addition, the Company provides
certain health care and life insurance benefits (the Postretirement Plan) to
retired employees, limited to those receiving benefits or retired as of April
1, 1993.

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">(a)&nbsp;Settlements in the form of lump sum cash payments were made in fiscal 2001
to plan participants in exchange for their rights to receive specified pension
benefits.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Total Company contributions charged to employee benefit expenses for the
Savings Plans were $7,433, $6,709 and $5,929 during fiscal 2003, 2002 and 2001,
respectively.

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The health-care cost trend rate used to measure the expected cost of the
Postretirement Plan benefits is assumed to be nine percent in 2004 declining at
one percent decrements each year through 2007 and one-half percent decrements
through 2009 to five percent in 2009 and each year thereafter. The health-care
cost trend assumption has a significant effect on the amounts reported. For
example, a one percent increase or decrease in the health-care cost trend rate
would change the accumulated postretirement benefit obligation by approximately
$401 and ($354), respectively, as of January&nbsp;31, 2004, and would change the net
periodic cost by approximately $25 and ($22), respectively, during fiscal 2003.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">F-38
</DIV>

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company&#146;s investment strategy is to obtain the highest possible return
commensurate with the level of assumed risk. Investments are well diversified
within each of the major asset categories.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The expected long-term rate of return is figured by using the target
allocation and expected returns for each asset class as in the table above.
The actual historical returns are also relevant. Annualized returns for periods
ending December&nbsp;31, 2003 have been as follows: 23.7% for one year and 6.7% for
five years.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company expects that there will be no minimum regulatory funding
requirements that will need to be made during the fiscal year ending January
29, 2005 but that voluntary tax deductible contributions of up to about $3,000
will be allowed under Internal Revenue Service (IRS)&nbsp;rules. No decision has
been made at this time on Company contributions.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Expected benefit payments are as follows over future years:

<DIV align="center">
<TABLE style="font-size: 10pt" cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="55%">

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On December&nbsp;8, 2003, the Medicare Prescription Drug Improvement and
Modernization Act of
2003 (the Act) was signed into law. Following the guidance of the FASB,
the Company has elected to defer recognition of this Act at this time. The
accumulated postretirement benefit obligation and net periodic postretirement
benefit cost do not reflect the effect of the Act on the Postretirement Plan.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">F-39
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">
<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS CONTINUED</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Specific authoritative guidance on the accounting for the federal subsidy is
pending and guidance, when issued, could require a change to previously
reported information.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Barnes &#038; Noble.com</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As of June&nbsp;30, 2000, substantially all employees of Barnes &#038; Noble.com
were covered under Barnes &#038; Noble.com&#146;s Employees&#146; Retirement Plan (the B&#038;N.com
Retirement Plan). The B&#038;N.com Retirement Plan is a defined benefit pension
plan. As of July&nbsp;1, 2000, the B&#038;N.com Retirement Plan was amended so that
employees no longer earn benefits for subsequent service. Subsequent service
continues to be the basis for vesting of benefits not yet vested at June&nbsp;30,
2000 and the B&#038;N.com Retirement Plan will continue to hold assets and pay
benefits.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Actuarial assumptions used in determining the funded status of the B&#038;N.com
Retirement Plan are as follows:

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Barnes &#038; Noble.com&#146;s investment strategy is to obtain the highest possible
return commensurate with the level of assumed risk. Investments are very well
diversified within each of the major asset categories.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The expected long-term rate of return is figured by using the target
allocation and expected returns for each class as in the table stated above.
The actual historical returns are also relevant. Annualized returns for
periods ending December&nbsp;31, 2003 have been as follows: 23.7% for one year and
6.7% for five years.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Barnes &#038; Noble.com expects that there will be no regulatory funding
requirements that will need to be made during the fiscal year ending December
31, 2004. It is also expected that the maximum tax-deductible contributions
will be $0 under IRS rules.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Expected benefit payments for the B&#038;N.com Retirement Plan are as follows
over future years:

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At December&nbsp;31, 2003, bn.com, which files separate tax returns, had net
operating loss carryforwards of approximately $137,028 related to U.S. federal
and state jurisdictions. These amounts begin to expire in 2010 and are subject
to certain limitations under the Internal Revenue Code. Due to the current
uncertainty regarding the realization of the related deferred tax asset of
approximately $51,424, a full valuation allowance has been provided. Assuming
the Company completes the acquisition of bn.com in
fiscal 2004, it will be included in the Company&#146;s federal income tax
return and a


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">F-43
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">
<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS CONTINUED</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">portion of this deferred tax asset may become realizable.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>12. GameStop Initial Public Offering</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In fiscal 1999, the Company acquired Babbage&#146;s Etc., one of the nation&#146;s
largest video-game and entertainment-software specialty retailers, a company
majority owned by Leonard Riggio, for $208,670. An independent Special
Committee of the Board of Directors negotiated and approved the acquisition on
behalf of the Company. The Company made an additional payment of $9,665 in
2002 due to certain financial performance targets having been met during fiscal
year 2001.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On June&nbsp;14, 2000, the Company acquired all of the outstanding shares of
Funco, Inc., a Minneapolis-based electronic games retailer for approximately
$167,560. The acquisition was accounted for by the purchase method of
accounting. The excess of purchase price over the net assets acquired, in the
amount of approximately $131,400, has been recorded as goodwill and is tested
for impairment at least annually, in conformity with SFAS No.&nbsp;142.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Through a corporate restructuring, Babbage&#146;s Etc. became a wholly owned
subsidiary of Funco, Inc. and the name of Funco, Inc. was changed to GameStop,
Inc.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In February&nbsp;2002, GameStop completed an initial public offering of shares
of its Class&nbsp;A common stock at a price of $18.00 per share, raising net
proceeds of approximately $348,000. A portion of the net proceeds was used to
repay $250,000 of indebtedness to the Company, with the Company contributing
the remaining $150,000 of indebtedness to GameStop as additional paid-in
capital. The balance of the net proceeds (approximately $98,000) was used for
working capital and general corporate purposes for GameStop. The Company
currently owns approximately 64&nbsp;percent of the outstanding shares of GameStop&#146;s
capital stock through its ownership of 100&nbsp;percent of GameStop&#146;s Class&nbsp;B common
stock, which represents 94.5&nbsp;percent of the combined voting power of all
classes of GameStop voting stock. The Company recorded an increase in
additional paid-in capital of $155,490 ($90,184 after taxes), representing the
Company&#146;s incremental share in the equity of GameStop.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>13. Segment Information</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company operates under two strategic groups that offer different
products. These groups have been aggregated into two reportable operating
segments: book operating segment and video game operating segment.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Book Operating Segment</I>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;This segment includes bookstores primarily under the Barnes &#038; Noble
Booksellers and B. Dalton Bookseller trade names. The 647 Barnes &#038; Noble
stores generally offer a comprehensive title base, a caf&#233;, a children&#146;s
section, a music department, a magazine section and a calendar of ongoing
events, including author appearances and children&#146;s activities. The 195 B.
Dalton stores are typically small format mall-based stores. In addition, this
segment includes Barnes &#038; Noble.com (an online retailer of books, music and
DVDs/videos), the Company&#146;s publishing operation (which includes Sterling
Publishing) and Calendar Club (a majority-owned subsidiary of the Company that
operates seasonal kiosks and seasonal stores). The book operating segment
employs a merchandising strategy that targets the mainstream consumer book
market.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">F-44
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>


<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">
<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS CONTINUED</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Video Game Operating Segment</I>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;This segment includes 1,514 video game and PC-entertainment stores
primarily under the GameStop trade name, a Web site (www.gamestop.com) and <I>Game
Informer </I>magazine. The principal products of these stores are comprised of
video-game hardware and software and PC-entertainment software.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The accounting policies of the segments are the same as those for the
Company as a whole. Segment operating profit includes corporate expenses in
each operating segment. The Company evaluates the performance of its segments
based on operating profit.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Summarized financial information concerning the Company&#146;s reportable

<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="right">(1)</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>On September&nbsp;15, 2003, the Company acquired a controlling interest in
Barnes &#038; Noble.com. As a result, the Company no longer records its
investment in Barnes &#038; Noble.com under the equity method of accounting.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>


<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="right">(2)</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Fiscal 2002 operating profit is net of an impairment charge of $25,328.
Excluding the impairment charge, fiscal 2002 operating profit would have
been $202,369. Fiscal 2001 operating profit is net of legal settlement
expense of $4,500. Excluding the legal settlement expense, fiscal 2001
operating profit would have been $216,200.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">F-45
</DIV>

    <TD width="4%" nowrap align="right">(a)</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Relates primarily to the acquisition of an approximate 37&nbsp;percent

assessment that is subject to revision as more detailed analysis is

</TR>

</TABLE>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During the first quarter of fiscal 2003, the purchase price related to the
acquisition of Sterling Publishing was allocated based on the valuation
performed by an independent firm. As a result, $48,176 was reallocated from
goodwill to the intangible assets noted above retroactive to February&nbsp;1, 2003.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>16. Shareholders&#146; Equity</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In fiscal 1999, the Board of Directors authorized a common stock
repurchase program for the purchase of up to $250,000 of the Company&#146;s common
shares. As of January&nbsp;31, 2004, the Company has repurchased 8,807,700 shares at
a cost of approximately $189,661 under this program. The repurchased shares
are held in treasury.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Each share of the Company&#146;s Common Stock also entitles the holder to the
right (the Right) to purchase one four-hundredth of a share of the Company&#146;s
Series&nbsp;H Preferred Stock for $225. The Right is only exercisable if a person
or group acquires 15&nbsp;percent or more of the Company&#146;s outstanding Common
Stock or announces a tender offer or exchange offer, the consummation of
which would result in such person or group owning 15&nbsp;percent or more of the
Company&#146;s outstanding Common Stock.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">F-47
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">
<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS CONTINUED</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>17. Impairment Charge</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During the first quarter of fiscal 2002, the Company deemed the decline in
value in its available-for-sale securities in Gemstar-TV Guide International,
Inc. (Gemstar) and Indigo Books &#038; Music Inc. (Indigo) to be other than
temporary. The investments had been carried at fair market value with
unrealized gains and losses included in shareholders&#146; equity. Events such as
Gemstar&#146;s largest shareholder taking an impairment charge for its investment,
the precipitous decline in the stock price subsequent to the abrupt resignation
of one of its senior executives, the questioning of aggressive revenue
recognition policies and the filing of a class action lawsuit against Gemstar,
were among the items which led to management&#146;s decision to record an impairment
for its investment in Gemstar of nearly $24,000 (before taxes). The Company&#146;s
decision to record an impairment charge for its investment in Indigo was based
on a review of Indigo&#146;s financial condition and historical share trading data.
As a result, the Company recorded a non-cash impairment charge to operating
earnings of $25,328 ($14,944 after taxes) to reclassify the accumulated
unrealized losses and to write down the investments to their fair market value
at the close of business on May&nbsp;4, 2002. In the second quarter of fiscal 2002,
the Company sold its investment in Gemstar resulting in a loss of $297.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>18. Stock Option Plans</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company grants options to purchase Barnes &#038; Noble, Inc. (BKS),
GameStop Corp. (GME)&nbsp;and barnesandnoble.com inc. (BNBN)&nbsp;common shares under the
incentive plans discussed below. In accordance with SFAS No.&nbsp;123, the Company
discloses the pro forma impact of recording compensation expense utilizing the
Black-Scholes model. The Black-Scholes option valuation model was developed
for use in estimating the fair value of traded options which have no vesting
restrictions and are fully transferable. In addition, option valuation models
require the input of highly subjective assumptions including the expected stock
price volatility. Because the stock options have characteristics significantly
different from those of traded options, and because changes in the subjective
input assumptions can materially affect the fair value estimate, in
management&#146;s opinion, the Black-Scholes model does not necessarily provide a
reliable measure of the fair value of the companies&#146; stock options. The pro
forma effect on net income and earnings per share, had the Company applied the
fair-value-recognition provisions of SFAS No.&nbsp;123, is shown in Note 1.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>BKS Stock Option Plans</I>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company currently has two incentive plans under which stock options
have been granted to officers, directors and key employees of the Company, the
1991 Employee Incentive Plan (the 1991 Plan) and the 1996 Incentive Plan (the
1996 Plan). Additionally, options may continue to be granted in the future
under the 1996 Plan. The options to purchase common shares generally are issued
at fair market value on the date of the grant, begin vesting after one year in
33-1/3&nbsp;percent or 25&nbsp;percent increments per year, expire 10&nbsp;years from issuance
and are conditioned upon continual employment during the vesting period.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The 1996 Plan and the 1991 Plan allow the Company to grant options to
purchase up to 14,500,000 and 4,732,704 shares of common stock, respectively.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In addition to the two incentive plans, the Company has granted stock
options to certain key executives and directors. The vesting terms and
contractual lives of these grants are similar to that of the incentive plans.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">F-48
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">
<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS CONTINUED</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Leonard Riggio, the Company&#146;s chairman, exercised 1,318,750 stock options
in September&nbsp;2003, by tendering in payment of the exercise price of the stock
options 606,277 shares that he held in the Company&#146;s stock. Mr.&nbsp;Riggio elected
to defer receipt of the balance of the shares (712,473) due from the exercise
pursuant to the Company&#146;s Executive Deferred Compensation Plan. In accordance
therewith, the Company established a rabbi trust for the benefit of Mr.&nbsp;Riggio
which holds 712,473 shares of the Company&#146;s common stock. The shares held by
the rabbi trust are treated as treasury stock. Due to the deferred
compensation arrangement these shares are included in the denominator of the
EPS calculation in accordance with SFAS No.&nbsp;128, &#147;Earnings per share&#148; when the
impact is not antidilutive.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The weighted-average fair value of the options granted during fiscal 2003,
2002 and 2001 were estimated at $8.02, $8.96 and $10.13, respectively, using
the Black-Scholes option-pricing model with the following assumptions:
